rivatives can, in high 
concentrations, act as pathogenic factors in oxidative stress and CVD [17]. 
Animal studies suggest that low-protein diets (5–8%) are associated with endocrine and metabolic 
abnormalities and intrauterine growth restriction [11,17]. The offspring demonstrate: impaired glucose 
tolerance and β-cell dysfunction – T2DM, hyperinsulinaemia, insulin resistance and hypertension [3,17,19] – 
and risk of possible impaired adult bone health [11,20].
